title: Effect of Elderberry Juice on Cognition and Inflammation in Patients With Mild Cognitive Impairment
description_brief: Elderberries (Sambuci fructus) have been shown in a number of studies to have significant anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects. Multiple human and animal studies have supported the anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects of elderberry preparations and it has been used in natural medicine for hundreds of years. Studies examining factors that may decrease the risk of Alzheimer's disease have revealed that drinking juices with similar properties to elderberries is one of the most reliable way to decrease risk. As such the investigators wish to determine the effects of elderberry juice on cognitive decline in a group of subjects at high risk for Alzheimer's disease, those with mild cognitive impairment. Elderberry juice is a commercially available nutritional supplement and easily available to this population.

groups.title: Elderberry Juice
groups.description:
Participants will drink 5ml of elderberry juice, diluted in 8oz of water, 3 times per day for three months.

Elderberry Juice

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Visuospatial Problem Solving Battery (VSP)
outcomeMeasures.description: Problem solving task for detecting non-memory impairments in MCI. Change in score is the outcome measure. The task is a timed task, with the outcome measured in seconds. Each item was allowed 240 seconds for solution, with times averaged for items. Therefore, there was a range of 0-240 with lower being better.

outcomeMeasures.title: Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: Assesses memory, orientation, judgement and problem solving, community affairs, home/hobbies, personal care. Change in CDR was the outcome. CDR ranges from 0 to 3, with 3 being worse.

outcomeMeasures.title: Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)
outcomeMeasures.description: Screening for cognitive impairment sampling functions including arithmetic, memory and orientation. Change in MMSE was the outcome. the MMSE is a scale from 0 to 30 with a higher score being better.

outcomeMeasures.title: Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT)
outcomeMeasures.description: Assesses verbal learning and memory. Change in the HVLT was the outcome measure. The range for the HVLT is 0-36 with higher representing better memory.

outcomeMeasures.title: Boston Naming Test (BNT)
outcomeMeasures.description: Measures word retrieval. Change in the BNT is the primary outcome measure. The range is 0-60 with higher representing better performance.

outcomeMeasures.title: Rey Complex Figure Task (Rey)
outcomeMeasures.description: Participants reproduce complicated line drawings. Change in the Rey was the primary outcome measure. The range of the Rey is 0-36 with a higher score being better performance.

outcomeMeasures.title: Anagrams
outcomeMeasures.description: Rearranging letters to form words. Change in performance is the primary outcome measure. The task is timed, with each anagram allowed 120 seconds, so each word has a range of 0-120 seconds, and the average for the latency was calculated, for a range of 0-120 with lower numbers being better.

outcomeMeasures.title: Instrumental Activities of Daily Living Scale (IADLS)
outcomeMeasures.description: Assesses daily self-care activities. Change in the IADLS is the primary outcome. Total items were added together for this use of the task, so the range was from 0 to 23, with higher being better.

drug: Elderberry juice (Sambucus nigra / Sambucus nigra subsp. canadensis)
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is elderberry juice — a commercially available nutritional supplement (Sambucus nigra / S. nigra subsp. canadensis) with reported antioxidant and anti‑inflammatory properties; the trial tests its effects on cognition in people with mild cognitive impairment (MCI), indicating the intended effect is cognitive improvement rather than a targeted anti‑amyloid/tau biologic or single small‑molecule inhibitor. citeturn0search5turn0search3

Act (extracted details): The randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled trial gave American elderberry juice (5 mL orally three times daily for 6 months) to older adults with MCI and measured cognitive domains and inflammatory markers; the product is a complex plant extract (polyphenols/anthocyanins) rather than a defined biologic or single small molecule. citeturn0search5turn0search7turn0search4

Classification rationale: By the category definitions provided, this trial best fits 'cognitive enhancer' — a nutritional/nutraceutical intervention aimed at improving cognition (and reducing inflammation) without being a monoclonal antibody/vaccine (disease‑targeted biologic) or a designed small‑molecule disease target drug. Although the mechanism (anti‑inflammatory/antioxidant) could be disease‑modifying in principle, the intervention is a complex food/supplement and the trial endpoints focus on cognition and inflammation rather than a specific pathological target (e.g., amyloid/tau). citeturn0search5turn0search0

Reflect: The classification aligns with the study title and design (Effect of Elderberry Juice on Cognition and Inflammation in Patients With MCI) and with published trial results showing feasibility, some trends toward improved visuospatial cognitive flexibility, and reductions in some peripheral inflammatory markers — supporting the interpretation as a cognitive‑focused nutraceutical intervention rather than a disease‑targeted biologic or small molecule. If you want the alternative interpretation (label it as potential disease‑modifying due to anti‑inflammatory action), note that would be a nonstandard mapping given the provided category definitions. citeturn0search5turn0search6
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is elderberry (Sambucus nigra / S. nigra subsp. canadensis) juice — a nutraceutical with documented anti‑inflammatory and antioxidant activity — and the trial title and endpoints focus explicitly on cognition and inflammatory markers, indicating the study tests an anti‑inflammatory cognitive intervention. citeturn0search0turn0search4

Act (extracted details): Randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled trial in older adults with MCI gave 5 mL elderberry juice orally three times daily for 6 months; the juice contains anthocyanins (mainly cyanidin‑3‑glucoside ~15.9 mg/5 mL) and the study measured cognitive domains plus peripheral inflammatory markers. citeturn0search7turn0search0

Mechanistic evidence (supporting the mapping): Preclinical and clinical literature shows elderberry extracts reduce proinflammatory mediators (e.g., IL‑6, TNF‑α, NO, COX‑2, iNOS), inhibit NF‑κB signaling, and exert antioxidant effects via Nrf2/HO‑1 and related pathways — consistent with an anti‑inflammatory mechanism of action. citeturn0search5turn0search1turn0search3

Classification rationale: The primary biological focus inferred from the trial (measuring inflammatory markers and using a product with documented anti‑inflammatory actions) maps best to CADRO category F) Inflammation. Elderberry’s antioxidant/oxidative‑stress actions are relevant but secondary (CADRO G), so the most specific single category is F rather than R) Multi‑target. citeturn0search2turn0search4

Reflect: The F) Inflammation assignment aligns with the trial’s stated outcomes and the known bioactivity of elderberry juice. If one insisted on capturing both antioxidant and anti‑inflammatory mechanisms equally, an alternative would be R) Multi‑target, but given the trial emphasis on inflammatory markers the preferred CADRO classification is F) Inflammation. citeturn0search0turn0search3
